title: prophets
comment: Individuals called and empowered by God to declare his will to his people, including the disclosure of his future intentions to save and judge his people. The term refers particularly to the great OT prophets, such as Isaiah and Jeremiah, who were raised up to guide the people of God at critical moments in their history and whose ministries and teaching remain of continuing importance today. At several points in his ministry, Jesus Christ was acclaimed as a prophet.

children.title: prophets, role of
children.comment: As agents of God, prophets acted in various capacities, as was required of them, in order to carry out his will and fulfil his purpose.

children.title: They conveyed messages from God to the nations

primaryrefs.comment: The intermediary role of the prophet is highlighted by the image of a watchman who receives messages from God and conveys them to the people.

children.title: Prophets as leaders in the community
prophets, false
children.comment: Men or women who falsely claim to speak on God's behalf. They are denounced in the OT and NT for leading people astray. Scripture provides criteria by which true prophets may be recognised and distinguished from false prophets, who often speak from base motives.

children.title: A true prophet's word will be fulfilled
A true prophet's teaching commends righteous behaviour
A true prophet's godly life will reflect his calling
A true prophet will acknowledge Jesus Christ as divine
Their messages may be occasioned by popular demand
Their messages may be given for financial reward
Their messages may be the result of deception
Their messages may be inspired by divination
prophets, lives of
children.comment: God called individuals from differing backgrounds to speak as prophets on his behalf, sometimes in difficult circumstances.

secondaryrefs.comment: Moses was brought up in the Egyptian royal court
Samuel was a temple servant at Shiloh
Ezekiel was a priest living in exile in Babylonia.

children.title: The family life of the prophets

secondaryrefs.comment: Elijah did not die but was taken up in a chariot of fire.
